displayed_text: Healthcare Professional: Yes! Doctor: Yep! Healthcare Professional: Do your thing. Family Member: Hey. How are you? Doctor: I hear I’m missing the show in here. Patient: Your hands are cold, doc. Doctor: I just washed ‘em. How are you? Family Member: They are cold. Doctor: Okay! What are we going to do? (chair movement) Family Member: Can you -- I’m lost here. Can you repeat – uh, why -- are you saying that he could go on the next trial? Doctor: You could try a trial and see how you do – Patient: Right. Doctor: And then, if somewhere along the way, it improves, great. I’m talkin’ about the fistula and this whole –

Family Member: But you know he’s bad about taking his pain pills, too. Family Member: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting? Doctor: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain. Family Member: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it? Doctor: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic. Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel – Doctor: Exactly. So I want to just poison you one thing at a time. Family Member: Poison (chuckles) Doctor: Okay? Patient: And the V___ Patient: I was seeing a doctor V___ in O____ in D____. Doctor: That’s him.

Patient: All right. So this is the best. This is the best option that you're thinking right now. Doctor: Mhm. Yeah. It keeps you on things that you haven't really broken through, but your pills are starting to do this. They’re starting to tread water. And I'm like, “Hold up!” before you start to sink. Let me see if we can throw a lifeline. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So a lot of the prostate cancer trials are like that now. So we're like, I'm okay. I'm okay. And then you’re like uh oh I’m starting to fade. And so we have all these new pills that are like, wait- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: - I'm gonna come and help you. Patient: Okay, so. Doctor: Okay. Patient: All right. Doctor: Well, good. It was nice to see you. I'm glad we had a chance to chat and you know, if it's good then call M___ and I’ll tell her to be on the lookout. Patient: Okay. So it's up to me to call her and let her know. Doctor: Well I’ll have her call you too. But that way, you know that at your convenience if you're at work, and she calls you that you can call her back. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah that’s fine. Family Member: That’s fine because I could set up an appointment with him to just kind of go over things and I don’t know when they’ll want him to start. Doctor: When your control is better. Family Member: Do we decide that or do we come see you again first? Doctor: You decide it with Dr. F___ but don’t rush into it. Patient: Right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: What do you do? Family Member: I’m a physical therapist, but I manage the rehab department at C____. Doctor: What’s your phone number? For whoever is going to take a phone call. Family Member: You’re giving all the phone calls to me (Laughs) Doctor: Let me just write down who you are.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: …to produce… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …or get their machinery organizes, organized or orchestrated, there’s music… Doctor: …enough to produce enough PSA that we can detect in our blood tests… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …then you know it may take a little while for that to show up. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So you want, you want to, want me - want to know if I want to become involved in a particular? Doctor: I think you would be an excellent candidate for this study because that is obviously the question of the day… Patient: Sure. Doctor: …is whether or not we go for radiation therapy currently or whether or not we just kind of hold tight and check your PSA.

Patient: No I haven’t. Doctor: Okay. So we’d like to check your blood test and then call you and if the PSA is not down to zero then we would consider having you get some radiation treatments and send you for a consultation with the radiation doctors. Patient: Mmm. Doctor: If the PSA does go down to zero then we can tell you about some additional testing that we can do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we may do um your paperwork here - an appointment for six months, just kind of like a safety appointment. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But we’ll be talking to you within the next few days and seeing if we have to alter the plans at all. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: So what you think my tests might be? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll find out by tomorrow. Patient: Okay, that’ll be good.

Patient: Right. Doctor: radiation but that time has passed and I’m just gonna recap where we are so we have a plan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I told you you’re making me work hard. Patient: I know. Doctor: But I’ve been thinking about you since we can’t get these trials to gel and I told the gals over there I said listen the minute we’re kind of fumbling around, stop, back here. Because we have to reset in our ways because we’re not losing time but I hate not having a plan and you guys hate not having a plan. Patient: Right. Doctor: We just need a plan and know where we are. So, let’s just backtrack for a second. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If I say gosh, where is your cancer right now, I’m not sure if I can adequately answer that by scans because the last one you had at Oakwood, hold on. Patient: Right, same thing, yeah. Doctor: Same thing, was July and then we did a quick scan to make sure nothing was happening, you know, here after the biopsy but that was just sort of kind of like limited.

Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations. Patient: Okay as far as working what do you mean by that? I mean is it something… Doctor: Working against – shrinking the cancer and helping – working against the… Family Member: Targeting drugs and genes (doc and fam talking at the same time.) Doctor: Targeting exactly the cancer that you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now there is another option, I know you’re completely reluctant to go on chemotherapy. You know there is obviously that would be the standard treatment that you know we would – if we advise that and if you decide you want that you could easily get it in lots and closer to home.

Patient: But they didn’t explain to me what that meant. So what do you mean, stabilized? Does that mean that it’s not growing? Does it mean that it’s not, uh, progressing? Does it mean it’s not going the other way? What, what do you mean, stabilized? Doctor: Yeah. I think that meant that the, the CT and bone scan from August first and August second did not look any, any worse than the ones before that. They also didn’t look any better but the cancer had stopped growing and spreading further. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that what, you know, stabilizing means. So I’ve heard everything that you had to say. And it, it seems very clear that you’re leaning towards continuing on the study and I think that’s a reasonable idea. There has been nothing so far on this study that is an absolute reason to stop. An absolute reason to stop would be, for example, if your scans showed unequivocal progression of the cancer. That would be one reason. Another reason would be if your pain was getting so bad that we had to consider radiation to the bone to eliminate the pain. Uh, another would be if you had any, uh, very serious side effect to the medication that is not reversible. Uh, so, what I think we should do is this. It sounds like you want to try to give this a bit more time. I think that about two months from now, roughly, a bit less, because your scans were on August first and second, so, roughly, I think the first week of October, you’re going to be getting another CT scan and another bone scan, because this trial requires the scan every eight weeks. Uh, let’s try to keep you on the study until that point in time because that’s going to give us a lot more information about, you know, comparing that scan to the previous one and then comparing that scan to the very, very first one, your baseline, as we call it. Uh, plus by then, we’re going to have two more PSAs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: To see if that’s stabilizing at all. And we’re going to know also from you how you’re feeling in terms of your bone pain. Like, is it overall getting slightly worse over time or if that’s stabilized, or is it perhaps improving? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: In order to keep you on this study, uh, from the side effect perspective, we’re going to need to temporarily stop the medication again, unfortunately- Because of this hemoglobin being eight point nine. Okay? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, it’s very likely that when you come back on September fifth, your hemoglobin will be above nine, hopefully, above ten, it will recover some, in other words, uh, and then given that the hemoglobin has improved, we can put you back on the medication, but it will be at the two-hundred milligram dose. It’ll be a second level of dose reduction. Okay? Patient: Hum. Doctor: I don’t think you’ll need to go lower than that. Okay? But I think the two-fifty in terms of the anemia, uh, it did cause the same problem, again, to a lesser degree, but it did still cause the same problem. Uh, so my preference, if you want to remain on the study, which I think is reasonable, would be as of today to ask you to stop the medication until you come back and see us on September the fifth. And on that day, what we’re probably going to recommend, provided that your hemoglobin has increased again, preferably above ten, but at least above nine, is we’re going to put you back on the second dose level reduction which will be two hundred milligrams per day.

Family Member: No, no, no, no. Doctor: Because I don’t want them you know working too hard. Patient: Right, right, right. Doctor: Right, since we are starting the chemo, it’s sort of - Patient: Aggravating, that situation - Doctor: It’s a new medicine. Family Member: Right, right, right. Doctor: You know you don’t know how you’re going to react, so. Sit up for a minute. HCP Is that blister gone where he had a biopsy? Family Member: Yes, okay. Doctor: Yes, that’s (whispering while assessing patient) Patient: I just put some Icy Hot back there. Doctor: Okay. Does that seem to help?

Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me? Doctor: Okay. Patient: I need that, too. I don’t have a primary care doctor right now. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m ‘ppossed to, ‘pposed to go see one of the Wayne State guys next Thursday. Doctor: Yeah, because one day I’m gonna assign you somebody or something, and then your insurance changed? Patient: No, that one over there, I didn’t. That’s why I told them I didn’t want to come back over there no more. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I didn’t… they didn’t impress me. I mean, they fine (laughs) Doctor: Don’t tell me. They didn’t yell at you enough? Doctor: Okay. Patient: It’s south for you and I’m gonna start going there. Doctor: Okay, but I’ll send it in because I don’t want you to run around with high blood pressure either.

Patient: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have a one month version, we have a three month version, we have a year long version. We could start with the one-month version just to make sure things are okay. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And I could ask my nurse to get authorization for that. So I don’t think we could just give it to you right now. Patient: Right. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think she has to get it improved from you insurance company and then you could come back in a week or two and get it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And then you’ll have a consult. Family Member: Mm,hmm.

Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: So nobody goes in? Patient: Not unless they have to pick up something. They can't stay because there's not air conditioning. The HVAC is turned off. Doctor: Holy mackerel that’s like serious. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Do you think you guys will ever go back someday? Hard to say? Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything” Patient: Yeah I quit Lupron for that reason. Doctor: And you're just like, oh, man, I can't do it. Patient: So, what was the other doctor’s name? Doctor: J____. Family Member: J____. Patient: He asked about Lupron. He said Aligard. I said it’s the same thing. It’s not.

Family Member: In January. Doctor: So if you’ve already got an appointment for January – Family Member: January thirty. Doctor: Yeah, that will be your next shot. So typically I schedule that no matter what. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’re always going to come in and see me or (says name) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. And the chemo is what we’re here to talk about today- Patient: Okay. Doctor: It is you know if you’re still interested in the clinical trial, have questions for me about the clinical trial, then I’m going to bring D___ in. So she’s the research nurse that I’ll sort of is it doable, can we get started, and what you have to do to go forward, okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then once you guys sign the paperwork and we move forward, then you and I will pick a date to pick the day the chemo starts. Patient: Okay.
